content.title: W głąb translatorskiej nory | Literatura | Dwutygodnik

Alicja w krainie czarów wczoraj i dziś - 4 lipca 1865 roku, a więc niemal równo 150 lat temu, ukazało się pierwsze wydanie Alicji w krainie czarów Lewisa Carrolla. Tłumacz Maciej Słomczyński w przedmowie do wydania z 1965 roku napisał, że jest to zapewne jedyny wypadek w dziejach piśmiennictwa

results:
Based on the search results, I can provide information about Maciej Słomczyński's 1965 translation of "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland" ("Alicja w Krainie Czarów"):

Maciej Słomczyński's translation of "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland" was published in 1965 and was significant for several reasons:

**Key Features of Słomczyński's Translation:**

It was the first Polish translation that was faithful to the original, published exactly 100 years after Lewis Carroll wrote the book (1965), and was the first translation consistent with the original without additional comments or alterations.

This translation is characterized by a relatively large number of Anglicisms, and in the preface to the second edition, the translator explained that his goal was to bring Alice closer to the adult reader.

**Translator's Philosophy:**

In his preface to the 1965 edition, Słomczyński wrote that "this is probably the only case in the history of literature where one text contains two completely different books: one for children and another for very adult readers".

Słomczyński repeatedly emphasized (including in his introduction) that he was primarily concerned with bringing "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland" closer to the adult reader.

**Significance:**

This is the second most popular Polish translation of Alice, and it enjoys great popularity alongside Robert Stiller's 1986 translation.

The translator compared Lewis Carroll to James Joyce, highlighting that "Alice in Wonderland" doesn't really belong to the world of children's fantasy, although it can certainly be read by the youngest readers as well.

The translation was groundbreaking for being the first accurate Polish rendition that preserved Carroll's original intent and literary complexity.
